repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Critical Electricity and
            Water Services Rehabilitation Project for Chad were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory; the risk to
            development outcome was high; the Bank's performance
            was unsatisfactory; and the Borrower's performance was
            also unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: scope of
            Project Development Objectives (PDO) in fragile states. PDOs
            should be simpler, less ambitious and more realistic for
            countries with limited implementation capacity and a fragile
            political environment. The time estimated for project
            implementation should also be more realistic. Choice of
            investment activities and assessment of project economic
            benefits in fragile states. Willingness to enforce remedies
            in the context of a tense dialogue between the bank and the
            borrower. Compliance with safeguard obligations in fragile
            states. Level of investments and implementation arrangements
            for infrastructure investments in fragile states. Importance
            of realistic risk assessment and appropriate mitigation measures.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Critical
            Electricity and Water Services Rehabilitation Project for
            Chad are to: a) secure the delivery of basic electricity and
            water supply services and prevent the collapse of the system
            particularly in N'Djamena; (b) reduce the costs of
            electricity and water supply services; and (c) support
            increased private sector participation in the sectors. This
            memorandum requests the approval of the Country Director
            for: (i) an exceptional retroactive extension of the closing
            date for the project to allow the payment of outstanding
            bills under the project (amounting to US$0.6 million); and
            (ii) a reallocation of credit funds. A waiver for the
            exceptional retroactive extension of the credit closing date
            was approved by the Managing Director on November 11, 2010.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project, seeks to secure the
            delivery of basic electricity, and water supply services, to
            prevent the collapse of the system, particularly in
            N'Djamena, in addition to reducing service delivery
            costs, through an increased private sector participation in
            both sectors. The first component will provide resources to
            maintain, and in some cases increase the delivery of
            electricity services in N'Djamena and in six smaller
            urban centers, through the rehabilitation, and expansion of
            electricity production, transmission, and distribution
            systems. Expansion, and rehabilitation of water supply
            systems will be implemented under a second component,
            likewise in the city of N'Djamena, and in eight smaller
            urban centers. The third component will improve the
            technical, commercial, and environmental performance of the
            Societe Tchadienne d'Eau et d'Electricite (STEE),
            including personnel safety standards as well. Preparatory
            activities required to prepare the second phase of the
            investment program will be implemented under the fourth
            component, as will the preparatory activities required to
            initiate the second phase of the investment program, and
            project oversight.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            potential environmental risks as a result of the Critical
            Electricity and Water Services Rehabilitation Project
            implementation, namely, hydrocarbon soil pollution due to
            the absence of retention zones at critical sites, revealing
            numerous leaks, thus polluting surface waters, and air
            quality, as well as endangering the well-being of urban
            populations in the surrounding area of Farcha, in
            N'djamena, where the new power plant will be
            constructed, and the existing one rehabilitated. Mitigation
            measures will primarily ensure the appropriate disposal of
            solid wastes, while lubricants and chemicals will be
            disposed of at selected sites, following special treatment
            regulations. Equipment and machinery will undergo specific
            maintenance to control air, and noise pollution, in
            accordance with the country's legislation. Wastewaters
            will be collected at a particular sewage site, to be treated
            prior to discharge in natural habitats; conversely,
            wastewaters potentially carrying hydrocarbons, will undergo
            a specific separation treatment, but will not be discharged
            into natural habitats, rather into a selected lagoon to
            undergo a natural evaporation treatment. Industrial
            wastewaters will be collected separately, treated in septic
            type tanks, prior to disposal into natural habitats.
            Transformers containing PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls)
            will not be allowed, as neither will substances containing
            asbestos, nor lead. Landscaping, and vegetation propagation
            will be conducted, aiming at containing soil erosion, and
            purifying air quality.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Critical Electricity and Water
            Services Rehabilitation Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan (RAP)
            includes an introduction explaining the critical situation
            of the electricity, and water sector in Chad, and, presents
            the objectives of the RAP, specifying the need to avoid,
            and/or minimize as possible the relocation of populations,
            that project affected people (PAPs) must be consulted prior
            to resettlement, and that their living conditions must be
            improved, or at least maintained, which includes employment,
            access to social and medical services, and to transport.
            Based on a socioeconomic survey, the RAP determines the
            eligibility criteria, and budgetary estimates for household,
            and structure losses, within the country's legal
            framework, and the Bank's policy on involuntary
            resettlement. Compensation will be conducted at replacement
            costs for land losses, housing and structures, to be
            replaced by a licensed builder. In addition, asset losses,
            including trees and crops, or storage facilities will also
            be replaced at equal values, and, transportation moving
            costs will be provided. An appeals process will be in place
            to conduct disagreement, or conflict resolution cases. And,
            a monitoring and evaluation process will ensure the
            successful outcome of the resettlement process, implemented
            by a nongovernmental organization, specialized in social
            services, participatory methods, and socioeconomic studies.
